results.title: Occupational First Aid
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Occupational First Aid is the emergency treatment for accidents or illnesses which occur in the workplace. This program looks at the skills required to be a First Aider and at the content and location of First Aid kits in the workplace. First Aiders must be multi-skilled persons able to provide emergency treatment, make decisions regarding treatment or refer, dress and re-dress minor injuries, maintain and stock First Aid kits, actively participate in Safety programs and be familiar with the workplace.

results.title: Shock
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Utilising a number of scenario accident sequences, this program highlights the common factor to all injuries - Shock. Defines shock and examines actual and relative fluid loss. Looks at signs and symptoms and explains emergency treatment. Emphasises that shock is an ongoing process which must be treated and stopped.

results.title: Altered consciousness
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Examines and defines the altered consciousness state and the problems it causes, in particular, the patient being unable to recognise and thus react to dangers either external e.g. fire, or internal e.g. blocked airway. Looks at Epilepsy, diabetes and head injuries as specific examples. Emergency treatment included . WARNING-The Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria has advised that this program contains outdated information and shows practices no longer followed.

results.title: Heart Attacks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Explains the oxygen supply to the heart. Examines various abnormal heart conditions. Signs and symptoms for angina and coronary occlusion and emergency treatment required.

results.title: Airway
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Explains the anatomy of the upper and lower airway and, how simply it can become partially or totally blocked; the signs and symptoms of a partially blocked and totally blocked airway and the emergency treatment required under both conditions.

results.title: Burns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Causes and types of burns. Emergency treatment required. Looks closely at the treatment of a burnt leg and examines the situation of burns around the head and neck area which may have a serious effect on the patient’s ability to breathe. Treatment of the patient’s emotional state.

results.title: Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Function, location and anatomy of heart. Explains pulse and where to locate. With resuscitation model explains external compression and moves onto cardio-pulmonary resuscitation, firstly with one rescuer and then two rescuers. Based on the method taught by the Australian resuscitation council.

results.title: Life in the trees
results.creator_credit: Richard Attenborough, John Sparks, Reiner Moritz Productions, Warner Bros Pictures and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Life on Earth”.
David Attenborough examines the evolution of the primates. As well as looking at the better known members of the ape family - monkeys, gorillas and chimpanzees - it also looks at some of the lesser known cousins. This episode contains the memorable scene where David Attenborough meets a group of young mountain gorillas in Zaire.

results.title: The First forests
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Life on Earth”.
Part 3 of a series which traces the dramatic history of life on earth from its beginnings about 3,500 million years ago to the final emergence of man. In this episode David Attenborough discusses the evolution of plants from the first algae and moss-like plants that crept onto the land from the waters edge to the giant trees of todays forests, showing how they solved the two major problems of support and reproduction in the absence of water. The arrival of plants on land made it possible for animal life to live there as well and the evolution of the first plants and animals is inextricably linked. Also examines how plants grew taller, seeking light and how insects developed wings to reach their food sources. Microphotography is used to reveal unsuspected details of mosses, liverworts, ferns, cycads and conifers.
